pros: GE is definitely the place to mould yourself with the culture, integrity and organised structure and practices. The trainings are the best to ensure 100% utilization and learning for an employee. Integrity and the culture have always been open and very easy to understand. It's a great start up place to develop your skills, talent and understand what career path you are looking for.
cons: The salary could be higher compared to the job market. There are a lot of incentives, but the basic salary is pretty less.

pros: GE Transportation offers a great work environment. The people are friendly and make a great team.  They had a good mentorship program which had you reporting to a single engineer to learn and obtain work projects that could easily build up your skills.  The life-work balance was excellent..
cons: Some of the tasks could become repetitive and you could get yourself pigeon-holed into only doing a certain type of task if you don't actively seek out new challenges and responsibilities.

pros: exposure to leadership, training, good pay
cons: big company so there is a lot of bureaucracy, locations could be better

pros: It a great place to work, because you are exposed to vast technologies and a lot of subject matter experts that you can learn from to further you career.  Also, the company has a great set of values.
cons: Since it is a large corporation, there is a lot of bureaucracy when trying to get your job done.  Also, executives are very demanding, and due to this reason their is a poor work/life balance on entry level and mid-level managers.

job_title: Technical Project Engineer in Wilmington, NC
pros: Great town.  Minutes from the beach and 2 hrs south of  Raleigh, NC.  Great management and the teams are very helpful.
cons: Seems to be a bit of clique-ish.  They have their circle of engineers they know and trust and then there is all the rest trying to get in the "inner circle".

pros: GE Aerospace -- now no longer part of GE -- was technologically at the cutting edge of what we did.  Management focus, tracking progress, and support of their employees was very good.
cons: GE Aerospace would cut our budget requests by 5 to 15 percent but still require the same output.  Therefore we routinely requested more funds than might be needed to compensate for the expected shortfall in funding.  It was a stupid game, but we were good -- out of necessity -- at playing it.

pros: great way to gain experience and plenty of room for advancement whether in my field or in another part of the company
cons: Long hours and the environment can be cutthroat.  It would be better to have more opportunity to learn instead of having to feel anxious about my job and if I'll be able to succeed over my coworkers

review_title: So far very satisfied- learned a lot and have grown
job_title: Engineering Technical Leader in Greenville, SC
pros: Many opportunities to contribute and grow your career.  Hard work is recognized. Flexible work schedule can be arranged. No hard limit on vacation days as long as you complete your responsibilities
cons: Too many reviews and pressure to save cost; going back to old culture when we're not fast and nimble. Management tends to promote Engineers who are hired in the Edison track versus who aren't

review_title: Great start to a career but not for long term growth
pros:
- Huge community of really smart people - if you put yourself out there, you can learn a lot and make great connections. 
- Challenging and demanding environment forces you to learn and learn quickly
cons:
- Difficult to move quickly within GE. 
- Sales culture tends to be very "old school." 
- Some lack of diversity in terms of peer experience.

job_title: General Consultant in Lehigh Acres, FL
pros: Very friendly coworkers, worked at your own pace with minimal interruptions a lot of employees brought head phone sets and listened to music while they worked, casual dress and great pay.  Always had luncheons, pizza parties, and employee events.  They give their employees optional Fridays off during summertime so they can be home with their kids but of course take their work home.
cons: Employees seemed to be overworked a lot of them would take their work home with them.

job_title: Service Leader in Mission Viejo, CA
pros: The people, the benefits and the culture at GE is great. GE has been doing a great job to drive a successful business while becoming a company that truly cares about  their employees.
cons: While there is always a need to evaluate workforce to ensure operational effectiveness, efficiency, and cost savings, it occurs more often than preferred. 2 - 3 times a year on a year over year basis. It is only fair to state that this is just not GE specific, this is happening across the entire healthcare/medical device industry.

pros:
The people and environment is great! Everyone is busy, yet they are still happy to stop and help you! Additionally, as an intern you are not just given busy-work projects. I worked in the manufacturing plant, and the projects I were given had a big impact on the company. 

I value my time I had with GE!
cons: I worked approximately 10 - 13 hours per day.  It wasn't mandatory to work over-time, but my projects required me to stay in the plant longer than 8 hours.

pros: Brand name has great value, GE has its age and maturity in certain aspects such as ethics and culture.
cons: GE is a massive company, and every business has its own experience. Rating GE as a whole is difficult. From the Engineering perspective, GE is no longer the innovator it used to be in the 1980s. After GE exited the "technology" arena into "capital", the engineering legacy was dispersed and lost in its divestures and closures.

job_title: Senior Technical Manager in Orlando, FL
pros: Flexibility (work from home, part time), good experience, talented people.
cons: GE is going through some major cost cutting right now.

review_title: GE will fail due to hiring and promotion tactics
pros: The pros are probably the benefits, but that is pretty much it.
cons: The company is selling off and going down hill, but if anyone has been to their Twitter page you can see they aren't interested in the best candidates but are interested in unethical "progressive" hiring practices.  Instead of building up current employees who have passion to work ahead, they hire inexperienced colleges graduates and hire exclusively to meet  "diversity" instead of the best which are usually people already within the company that started from the bottom.

pros: Amazing products, truly global organisation. Very smart and hardworking people, definitely opportunities to develop leadership (subject to mobility), Would absolutely recommend, its such a great learning curve.
cons: Can feel like a small fish in a big ocean at times, business can be a bit cut throat with  massive decision made quickly e.g. to sell business segments off. You need to push for your own career development

review_title: Due to poor financial position, GE is struggling and the environment is toxic.
job_title: Senior Director Engineering in San Ramon, CA
pros: Large company experience, globally distributed company with many opportunities. Exposure to multiple industries and business units. Potential for future growth is there if they can address failed financial decisions.
cons: Constant change, lack of direction and clear goals and objectives makes for a challenging environment.  The culture is not great and the environment is depressing.

pros: Flexible Family time, prorated vacation days,  not micro managed,
cons: Promises not kept,  computer training on things that didn't pertain to job site which would take hours and days to complete.   not enough man power to not cause conflict if someone was off or called in sick or to cover work loads. No real pay increases.

pros: Challenging work. New technologies being pursued. Benefits not too bad but I’ve seen companies with better. Product line is exciting to watch being built.
cons: Horrible management. Very short sighted. Only looks out one quarter when making big cost-cutting decisions.  GE lied when they said that they will have 20,000 women in technology roles by 2020. With men in the management positions, women are overlooked for promotions or the first one out the door when layoffs occur. I even heard a male manager say that he thinks that women don’t want to work. The culture is toxic.

pros: I had a great level of responsibility. I had a very supportive manager and mentor that helped me to succeed. It was brilliant working for such a well renown company. There were opportunities to do volunteer work as well which looks great on my CV.
cons: The company is so big there is a sense of divide between the different departments and you only really have the opportunity to speak to people in your own department. You don't get a very detailed understanding of what the other departments on site do.

review_title: GE's a good starter for a career moving forward
pros: Huge company gives lots of opportunity to try many different areas. If you work in a certain area for a while, you can try a completely different type of work within the same company, same pension, etc. By staying within the same company you can keep your seniority while trying to advance your career in different ways.
cons: Since it's such a large company, you can find yourself in lots of bureaucracy.

review_title: GE Energy, tough reliable job that pushes your limits.
job_title: IT Program Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Stability -- harder you work,  the more you take upon yourself, the more you're rewarded.  Pension.
cons: It's a big company.  If you're looking for a smaller feel, this is not the place for you.  You have to prove yourself everyday or you'll be swallowed by the beast.

pros: GE is not afraid to stack on the responsibility, the amount of experience from this internship is pretty serious. I've learned a lot about being a professional.
cons: Material can sometimes be a bit dull, but the great thing about IMLP is you can start somewhere fresh in 6 months. Also it's a little tough to move from business to business.

review_title: It was a painful but worthy experience.
pros: Great place to get some real hands on industrial experience. The engineering problems are extremely challenging and rewarding. GE is great for new hires to settle down and grow within the company.
cons: Nothing gets done correctly. Instead of sucking it up and solving the problems, they tend to patch a solution and leave the problem for the next unlucky group of engineers.

pros: Friendly supervisors, weekends off ,decent starting salary,many raises,huge opportunitites to advance yourself within the company,and a work schedule that fits everyones needs.
cons: Not the best benefits package available,some jobs are very dirty and noisy,The on the job training could be more clear. You are shown what to do but a lot of the times why you have to do it a certain way.

pros:
Excellent career development environment. 
Vast resources spent on employee development. 
Preference is given to individuals that join GE through their corporate programs, especially a combination of FMP and CAS will definetly give an individual a fast-track career. 
GE is an excellent name to carry in your CV.
cons:
Quite bureaucratic and decisions often depending on US HQ. 
Despite that the growth of revenues comes from outside US there are few non-US senior executives.

review_title: Enjoyed the challenge but management felt clueless
pros: MNC experience and if in the right team, access to resources and opportunities is worth it. It all depends which team and how good at employee management the manager is.
cons: Performance appraisal system is one of the worst I have ever come across. Again it's all with how knowledgeable the manager is to determine how rewarding the experience is.

pros: The engineering management team was amazing to work with.  Some of the most intelligent and competent people I've ever worked with.
cons: The purchasing and accounting systems made it almost impossible to get vendors into the system and pay them once they were in.  All of the vendor support was in India and they would always refer me to the same website which was never able to help.  I couldn't get the lab equipment I needed because I couldn't pay the vendors.

review_title: GE is a great company to work for especially starting out as an intern or co-op. I'm glad I have the opportunity
job_title: I T Systems Engineer Co-op in Van Buren Township, MI
pros: Team based environment, opportunity for advancement, opportunity to grow and develop professionally, Celebration of Diversity and culture, great pay for interns and co-ops
cons: Atmosphere can be too laid back and boring, over hear about people getting laid off often

pros: I worked in the factory 16 yrs and for the international dept. 18 yrs. Excellent pay, travel, great working environment.
cons: Upper management cares only for the bottom line. Schenectady went from 36,000 employees in 1980 to around 4,000 now. No longer has a pension plan other than 401Ks. Threw 56,000 salaried retirees into a health exchange this year and hourly retirees next. WAS a good place to work.

review_title: GE Global Operations is the new GE
pros: Taking a giant company that has been around for years to the next level. Evolving company culture to attract millennials and empowering intelligent employees. If you have good ideas, they will be heard! Relaxed dress code (jeans Mon-Fri) and upper management and executives are easily accessible and encouraging.
cons: Acquisitions can make things messy when not consolidated. I can't really think of any con so far from my experience.

pros: Great people; great projects...stimulating work environment. There's never a dull day. High-impact projects that you can really get behind.
cons: Priorities often shift too quickly -- hard to stay focused. Also, typical large company issues (bureaucratic, sometimes slow to change -- though improving). Some managers manage only "up" instead of training, empowering their teams.

pros: Metrics-driven so performance evaluations feel fairer than other places.  There is an ability to move roles every couple of years.  In general, smart people.
cons: It is a huge company so it can feel bureaucratic at times.  Unless you are at the very top, salaries are lower than equivalent jobs in the marketplace.

review_title: Satisfied, not the place is you are not willing to work hard
pros: Energetic, challenging environment. Plenty of opportunities to grow. Hard working attitude is appreciated by the management and HR. Immediate performance feedbacks. Opportunities to work from home.
cons: Agressive and sudden changes. Sometimes projects are not well planned in advance. Missing culture of coaching. Goals are not always set and clear or simply change too fast. Bad work life balance.

review_title: Unprofessional, poor customer service management (GE Lighting Budapest Hungary)
pros: Atmosphere is relaxed. Boring environment, not stressful. Compensation and benefits are average. There would be a plenty of cases to be creative and to perform.
cons: A lot of slackers in the organization, no common targets, no rules, customer is the last, ineffective management. Innovation is not promoted, people with real potential will not get higher. The manager and some team leaders are very long time in the same position. Most of leaders burnt out, resulting in an environment of poor ideas. Talents leave and comfortable team members stay. There is never a responsible person if things are going wrong.

review_title: A company that every day tries to improve on what was done
pros: Dynamic & challenging meritocracy. Pushes out of your comfort zone. You are not defined or limited by your job description
cons: The expertise and efficiencies promised by the adoption of the service centre model have not been delivered and there is still a huge dependency on those left in the business.

job_title: Senior Process Engineer in Schenectady, NY
pros: Challenging projects, high level of responsibility and good salary.  Benefits are fair, but pension no longer offered.  Strong management training program.
cons: Business objectives are not clear as company transitions in a digital direction.  Management structure was bulky, but is flatting and maybe becoming less transparent.  Shifting corporate priorities resulting in force reductions.

pros: GE is so big that one can do anything once they have joined. It is easy to start in one field and end up in a totally different field.
cons: Co-workers will treat you like competition. Management preaches teamwork but creates an environment in which co-workers have no incentives to work together.

job_title: Technical Operations Leader in Niskayuna, NY
pros: Used to be a great place to work - especially early in your career - project leaders given a lot of visibility.  Projects challenging and the caliber of the employees was very high
cons: No long term strategy, leadership at the very top no longer values/understands what it takes to conduct quality research.  GE is not effective at commercializing new technology.

pros: Very open minded culture, real flexibility in working hours, challenging level of responsibility. You can have an impact if you take that extra mile.
cons: Low-middle range of salaries, and if you are in, a significant raise is an impossible mission. Sad, but talents must go away and come back to get market value for their knowledge. Low chance for international career opportunities.

pros: Good company, good pay & flexible time off.  If your in the right position and know the right people, you can grow in your career.
cons: Company has lots of consistent change, and direction seems to be confusing at times.  Going through major financial changes and laying off numerous persons now.

pros: Flexible work life balance, compensation is about right
cons: The ladder is blocked by red tape, double standards, "if it aint broke dont fix it", do more with less, expensive healthcare benefits ($$$), no professional training, uncertainty at times with no real answers, career paths seem to be designed to select persons. Core values are questionable

review_title: Very great or very terrible depending on what management "thinks" of you
pros: Louisville is a good city.  Being part of larger GE Company.
cons: Currently, a very challenging economic environment is hurting sales.  Also, the prospective of the business being purchased or spun-off is creating poor morale.

pros:
Big company with a strong performance compliance driven culture
Unlike some companies, you don't have to worry about you next paycheck
Pay is lower but the hours make sense
cons:
Doesn't really know what markets to be in
Court by surprise by the finance crisis & did not get out of real estate when it had the chance
Selling NBC when it's performing badly and at the bottom of the value cycle

review_title: Good training program with learning opportunities and career development
pros:
generally a good work-life balance
focus on developing talent and making sure FMPs have opportunities to learn
new initiative to focus on health of employees
finance function plays large part in decision-making
cons:
new healthcare plan is more costly
finance function is somewhat understaffed in many instances
lots of data requests can be cumbersome - always have some new plan/estimate to load and pitch out

pros: Visionary senior leadership... experts in their field... hard working, dedicated employees... ability to think and act big when the opportunity presents itself
cons: Meritocracy doesn't work for everyone... self promoters have a way of getting through the system... multiple layers for decision making hinders ability to be nimble in the marketplace

review_title: Good career advancement, but no work life balance
pros:
- good career prospect
- good training ground from technical knowledge perspective (very structural training program)
- good discipline across all functions
- working with smart & energetic talents
- high mobility
cons:
- very lean resources 
- working overtime almost everyday, no work life balance
- stressful working environment
- not forgiving. One strike, you will be out
- complex matrix organization with shared services in many areas

review_title: Amazing training opportunities and interaction with upper management but very little work/life balance.
pros: GE is a great place to build a foundation and get your training and development in early. Their leadership programs are well recognized. I've met so many smart people that are willing to talk about their careers and become your mentor.
cons: Little work/life balance and I can see many glass ceilings to diverse groups. Although there is a big push, it's difficult to get GE out of the old corporate America mindset. Not much forward thinking and innovation.

review_title: Love Jack Welch era. Not so enamored with Jeff Immelt era
pros: I have been here for 23 years and have a pension. I was also lucky to have been here in the 80's and 90's. We had great leadership, great process, and a much clearer vision if our future.
cons: Jeff Immelt has diluted our culture, Not improved any processes or execution capabilities, and tanked our stock price by 70%.

review_title: Challenging, but focused on evolutionary power generation
pros: Plenty of great locations, opportunity to shift to other GE businesses for career growth, & GE hires great people, so you are always surrounded by very talented co-workers.
cons: Long hours and stretched resources can impact work/life balance for employees at all levels.  You just have to be organized and prioritize to get it all done.

review_title: Great place to learn, tough place to innovate
pros: Lot's of different opportunities, easy to move around to take on different challenges.  Lot's of opportunities for training.
cons: To much momentum, hard to make changes or process improve.  To many people are satisfied or comfortable in their position - don't rock the boat attitude exists from the top down in many places.  To much overhead / wasted effort

pros:
Salary is not low, compared with the same job at other companies.
Well‐equipped with welfare and benefit. 
Flexible and well organized team structure.
Famous company (that works well for changing job.)
cons:
Lots of overtime. 
Rigid hierarchy for opportunity of salary and promotion, that is already determined by the name of a university you graduated. Your actual competency, career history, qualification acquired after graduate virtually don't matter.
Good learning opportunities prepared only for the upper 1%, and virtually nothing for the others.

review_title: The best place to work as a mechanical engineer in Mexico
pros:
Flex Time
Ownership
You own your projects
Great environment and colleagues
Very ethical
cons:
No succession plans
Not the best pay in the market
Work very dependant on the US
Very difficult to grow fast

pros:
There are the usual opportunities and benefits that come with working for a large multi-national company.
Good benefit structure. Good career opportunities in certain areas.
Good leadership from the Home Lending senior management team.
cons:
Low pay, poor conditions, constantly reducing bonus scales.
A micro-management culture.
A lack of communication in some areas where there is a lot of change can impact on department morale.
A jobs for the boys culture is prolific in the Home Lending departments.
Middle management are very set in their ways and do not always echo the messages from the senior management.

review_title: Never run out of new challenges
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth, competitive salary & benefits, challenging work.  Comprehensive training program.  You can go anywhere in the world with GE if you are willing to put in the hours and be flexible about moving.  Lots of different businesses to get involved in so you really never have an excuse to stop learning and growing.
cons: Very long hours, lots of bureaucracy. Sometimes the simplest things are the most difficult to get done due to all the layers in the company.

pros: Exposed to global mindset and requirement for team playing abilities is essential.
cons: Rotation of management on Corporate level can send mixed messages to those below. At times the want to save a penny does effect the smaller local GE business while the Global business carry's on regardless. This can sometimes leave a bitter taste.

review_title: Working here makes you better at swimming through ambiguity
pros: Leadership training/ corporate training has been really valuable, opportunities to travel have also been really good, best paying job in town, flexible work schedule
cons: Lots of red tape, nothing is ever easy even if it should be, not always clear who owns what, starting a new role is very ambiguous, very political, generally people are unnecessarily rude and mean, not an easy place to ask for help

pros: My co-workers and managers are great.  There are interesting project assignments.  The culture usually focuses more on finding a solution rather than finding someone to blame when something goes wrong.
cons: Since it is a large company, bureaucracy can come into play.  Competing metrics can sometimes be frustrating as well.

pros:
- Pay (they pay interns very well with overtime extra pay as well)
- Location services (gym, cafeteria, bus from building to parking lot)
cons:
- Sometimes you feel left out there with no real resources
- They say they will work around your part-time schedule but still expect you to put in full-time level of work

pros: Ok pay. Nice office. Great colleagues- great  friendships. Looks great on your CV- Global Brand.
cons:
Not very Clear JDs- big titles with little content
Rewards visibility more than productivity- It is who knows you that matters. More career opportunities if you are on a leadership programs.
Very long hours with no overtime. Rigid HR. Too many layers, slow decision making. 
Too many process changes that are not necessarily aligned.
Mid management mainly yes Men.

pros: Great company to work for. So many career opportunities for individuals looking to excel. Safety is very important @ GE and they do a great job in following procedures to keep all of us safe. GE site in Minnetonka continues to expand and grow. Everyone's friendly and supportive. Good Pay.
cons: So far so good, it has been 4 months for me and all I see is opportunity.

pros: There is a lot of flexibility and opportunities to move around within the company and you are encouraged to work yourself out of your current role.
cons: It takes a while to adjust to the culture and make sure attempts to be helpful aren't viewed as "too negative" or "too aggressive".

review_title: Good Company. Average Domain. Try healthcare or GE Aviation
pros: Employee Relationship, Benefits, Moderate but healthy politics. Responsibility, growth and advancement, Subsidized food and Volvo cabs. Transparent, effective, independent and supporting HR.
cons: Stressful work, Resource crunch, Discrimination against people who don't believe in flattery. Vague goals and undefined leadership. Validation team is competent but unsupportive.

pros: It was a great company to work for. Excellent pay and vacation. The overall compensation package is great, they even offer stock options as well
cons: The work load can be a bit of a overload. However it is something manageable. Also there can be travel and relocation involved if you want to love up.

review_title: Willing to invest in their employees
pros: There are a lot of opportunities for training, development, participating in different projects, etc.. in terms of trying different things - GE is a good place
cons: Too many changes and restructurings which do not allow people to master something, but people are rather in a constant state of catching up and trying to figure out what's going on. It is also sometimes challenging to chase people in different countries and time zones for things that you needed done yesterday.

review_title: It’s ok so far but I’ve seen better...
pros: Great pay, benefits, & retirement package. The hours are good as well & you be off on weekends 95% of the time
cons: Poor management, takes forever to get hired on permanent & they put whites b4 blacks on the totem pole. I’ve seen a few guys come in & get trained then pass up the person who trained them...

review_title: GE is a floundering due to failed leadership
pros: Lots of smart people in their engineering delivery and product management mid level management.
cons: Too many executive band leaders who lead poorly.  Galactic incapability of assimilating acquisitions,.  Controls system technologies are two to three years behind.  A culture of intellectual bullies.

review_title: Worst Place ever , don’t go there
pros: very flexible and good work life balance
cons: Low salaries comparing to market , you might get hired as a GE employee and to wake up the next day to find yourself sold to other company, people are very unfriendly in a way they don’t smile to each other or say Hi at the elevator, and last but not least The HR is probably the worst HR I ever met in my whole professional career, HR managers believe themselves are the goddess .

review_title: I would like to be a member of GE so that I can know more what I am now.
pros: Actually I am seeking a good and dynamic job to build up my career also give my 100% output to the company.
cons: I think everyone, everywhere have to face more challenges in career. So I think challenges make sure you a good and dynamic person in once career.

pros: you can work in any of their business you like and people from one business can go to other very easily. GE gives flexibilty in terms or working hours and can pretty much get a job anywhere in the world
cons: i dont see any problesm perse but I believe if you compensation is biggest factor than they are not leaders in that area

pros: Large people network spreading across various industries. Clout when dealing with suppliers. Many opportunities for career development and encouraged to broaden skill set.
cons: It is hard to gain visibility with so many employees. Depending on the industry you are in, career development is limited without relocation.

pros: Good experience overall. Assignments were moderately challenging, however, sometimes the lack of interest of managers would kill the motivation.
cons: I felt that GE is too focused on corporate greed than caring about their employees. It's strictly an OK place to work. If you have the caliber and skills, there are better places to work than GE. The sheer size of the company is intimidating and causes massive inefficiencies throughout the organization.

review_title: Above average employees for below average pay
pros: Education, visibility, etc. are all pros at GE.  They do a great job of training their employees.  Challenging work is also a pro.
cons: Pay is by far the biggest con.  They used to be known for average pay and above average benefits, but they now have below average healthcare.  Pay is still satisfactory, but you can get better elsewhere.

pros: The growth potential and leadership development programs at GE are tremendous and are definitely the strong point of the company
cons: Working as an employee at such a large company can make you feel overlooked and not cared about.  GE pushes their employees to the extreme and does not compensate well or recognize outstanding effort/performance.

review_title: Great experience.....great learning curve....lots of opportunities
pros: There is really an unlimted number of opportunities on every function, if you deliver results there is a great flexibility to increase responsabilities
cons: Salaries are below average, the fast promotion and great flexibility in some cases makes up for it

review_title: Great place to start, not good to finish
pros:
- Very talented and smart people
- Never boring, very challenging
cons:
- Benefits not the best vs industry
- Always following competition - (Appliances)
- Severely Understaffed in critical functions like engineering, quality, manufacturing.
- Work/life balance is a concept nobody in management knows

review_title: Lots of opportunity to progress but no one will hold your hand.
pros: Opportunity to progress and learn from top leaders in your field.  Company provides good benefits and there are great leadership development programs.
cons: Many layers of managment.  Pay is not up to par with other companies.  Systems and procedures are difficult to deal with if you are not used to life in a big company.

review_title: It’s a great company, but you have to be a GE type of  guy !!
pros:
-Company has technically competitive advantage over competitors
-GE in your resume is very good
-Except for cost, Customers are generally satisfied with the services received
-Unlimited access to training Technical or Commercial
-Lot of Opportunities for growing (although up to some level)
-Benefits package is very competitive
-Sr level Managers are ok.
cons:
-As any other metric oriented company, there are a lot of work to do to have it met and correctly measure
-Salaries are bit short from when they should

pros:
- Opportunities are everywhere, but they are what you make of them.
- Majority of people are great to work with and are generally very bright and willing to lend a hand.
- Advancement of technology and information sharing is paramount to driving innovation and future growth.
cons:
- Large corporation with complex organizational structure and lots of bureaucracy.
- Government oversight due to the nature of the business reduces speed of developing new technologies and slows new product introduction to the market.

pros: ability to have 4 jobs in 2 years, gain domain expertise, grow your network, work on projects that are very significant to the business (sometimes with $MM in impact). Six Sigma Green Belt Certification, 100% paid tuition to either Georgia Tech, NC State, or UCONN technical engineering masters degree.
cons: You must be committed and have a strong passion for engineering. Buisiness taught Graduate School courses are challenging and have large time commitments. Many deliverables are required outside the typical 40 hr work week.

review_title: Working at GE Transportation for 1.5 years now after merger.
pros: Competitive compensation, highly skilled technical co-workers, opportunity for advancement within GE, challenging and meaningful work, flexible working hours, equal opportunity employer
cons: Far too much time spent in meetings. Poor communication from management. High deductible health insurance plan. Inflexible company-wide policies that may or may not make sense for every working group.

review_title: Low growth conglomerate, struggling under the weight of its own hubris
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: some vestiges of its former glory remain in its instant name recognition, which is helpful on a resume
cons: it is simply too big to be innovative anymore and it is disheartening to watch desperate people who have clawed their way to the top, sometimes clamboring over their bosses' heads to get face time with their bosses boss, stab each other in the back to hold their positions in the midst of all the layoffs over the last five years.

review_title: Excellent environment, if you like what you're doing.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Van Buren Township, MI
pros:
The sense of being a part of something special was pervasive throughout the company, which you don't really see at many other places. 
Most managers treat their employees like adults, and are flexible.
Benefits are outstanding.

cons: All projects are same , no challenging new technologies stale. Good for people ready to settle down with families not someone starting their career and looking to find their career path and learn .

pros: Large company with many opportunities.  Challenging programs to work on with options to travel small or large amounts of the time.
cons: Large company and easy to get lost in the noise.  Large programs can make a work life balance difficult to accomplish.

pros:
Fortune 500 Company
Opportunities to grow career in different GE businesses if willing to relocate outside Melbourne
Job Security
Tuition Reimbursement
Good Salary

review_title: Don't come here for the pay or the motivation

pros: Fantastic opportunities to learn and grow professionally. Great people and products. Very dynamic learning environment. Fast promotion if you do well in your job.
cons: Demanding work load you need to be 100% devoted to work in order to succeed. Expectation to travel and be flexible in where you live and work. Change jobs quite frequently.

pros: Good work culture, education facilities, family support and insurance, flexibility in work and excellent integrity and ethics
cons: Lower salary band, mid managers are very different in style and attitude a impact employee retention a lot. Yet to improve growth path for mid career  (10+ yr) employees in India.

review_title: Be cautious of newly acquired businesses
pros: The benefits package is good.
cons:
Do not work for an aquisition comapny.  GE buys so many businesses but never fully integrates them.  You will not get the "GE experience."

pros: Flexible hours, nice office, regular trainings. I really liked that the company is open for people from diverse backgrounds.

Different roles within TA are not clarified, and TA sourcers have no visibility to the business / hiring managers.

pros: Many of the colleagues are great people to work with, and even work (with a lot of pressure) is sometimes fun to do. You can learn a lot about how to do things well and fast.
cons: Not only pressure is huge, but some of the supposedly called colleagues have rude forms and are not nice to work with.

review_title: Patience is a virtue, but could be worth it
pros:
Great global leadership programs for work and personal development
Various employee recognitions (merits, rewards, training)
Encourages growth by allowing for experimentation

May some take time to get where you want in terms of ideal position, compensation, training even after achieving excellent performances
Expect various levels of bureaucracy, but bureaucracy nonetheless

job_title: Team Lead in North Las Vegas, NV

job_title: Material, Tooling and Logistics Leader in Abu Dhabi, Abu Dhabi
pros: Of course love GE for creativity and progressive ideas
cons: Corrupted bosses  and poor compliance team

job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in Hartford, CT

review_title: Find ways to succeed and not fail.

review_title: EID Internship: Great for career development w/ competitive salaries

cons: EID interns don't technically get paid sick days but most managers will let you take them off anyway or let you make up hours.

pros: Great work-life balance in certain positions, leadership proactive about growth opportunities and employee evaluations.  Consistent performance review cycles and reasonable discussions on development needs.
cons: Seems that the opportunities exist only for engineers in most roles excluding HR and Finance.  Salary tends to be lower than other similar roles, but the 'brand' of employee is outstanding.

pros: good place to learn the fundamental knowledge of this fields ,best for the fresh graduate to gain experience  first for the entry level, benefits are good
cons: slowly raise salary, no pension currently , a little bit down pay in this fields , career develop spaces is limited  to engineer, try become expert in this field first.

pros: growth potential is good, networking potential while on a leadership type program, brand recognition and leveraging working for a large company
cons: pressures to work crazy long hours make work life balance a struggle, yearly reviews are not done very fairly, too many levels in organization and lots of meetings before things can be changed

pros: Interesting technology and work.  The direct people you work with are great.
cons: Impossible to meet deadlines, lacking resources, and constant "help" to meet deadlines.  You have to understand GE treats employees as a commodity and once you understand that everything makes more sence

review_title: encouraging professional growth with work-life balance

motivating management communication 
encouragment for self motivated ideas/designs for building/implementing features/product

review_title: Great for leadership and if you like being a cog
pros:
If you're in a program or your manager loves you, you get sent to training and it's awesome. 
A LOT of resources everywhere because GE is huge

You are a tiny cog in a giant machine and there is a point where you will get jaded about this.
Work culture is traditional (varying degree based on what site you're at) - think the opposite of Google and that would be accurate.

review_title: Work would be fun if schedules weren't so tight.

pros: The people are very good.  There is a lot of talent here.  The company has the resources to bring new products to market and to stay on the cutting edge.
cons: Company spends too much time focusing on shareholders and not enough time focusing on customers and employees.  Benefits have gone downhill tremendously over last ten years.

pros: good work culture, stable career, good benefits, flexible work hours. good salary only if you are working for management and leadership positions.
cons: Low salaries for technical work domain. Injustice in form of lower pay against rigorous work extracted from employees. Compensation much lower compared to other companies which offer good salary for same experience. No way to negotiate for salary.  One must find a new job in other organization in order to increase his pay.

pros: Salary EE’s allowed to deploy disruptive innovation on a continuous basis.  You have to work hard, given more than you can possibly get done.  Consider it refreshing, reflecting good old fashioned hard work that is expected and rewarded.
cons: The “good old fashion hard work” mentioned above does not cascade down to hourly workforce in the form of responsibility & accountability.  Too much entitlement mentality.

review_title: Great company for a self-motivated, ambitious person.
pros: The opportunities that only a company the size of GE can offer.  On the forefront of innovative technologies, and plenty of training opportunities for the self-paced, energetic learner.

review_title: Tremendous learning opportunities.  One of the largest and most successful businesses in the world,

job_title: Senior Applications Engineer in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: An Epique Fail in A Global Company

cons: Execution is an epique fail, senior management team is out of order to be in harmony with real sense of innovation. HR is totally seperate story, who never understands what GE does, and what the intend behind is.

pros: Lots of opportunities, good package, smart way of doing things..

pros:

pros: The people at GE Transportation are great to work with -- very supportive and want to help you advance your career. Accessible upper management as well.

pros: Diversity of experiences; breadth of business; some really smart, capable people from whom I learn new things every day

review_title: Difficult to advance if not starting in entry level management program

review_title: GE is a good place to gain experience that you will be rewarded for elsewhere.

pros: The company provides a lot of compensation and benefits for employees and has deep values that they are proud of. People can earn higher salaries in Western European countries.

review_title: Great company with room to grow and learn

- Collaborative
- Broad opportunities

pros:

pros: GE is a great place to start your career if you are hungry and ready to work hard. It is generally a meritocracy, but there are some leaders than slow things down.

review_title: Large company with TONS of change all the time!

review_title: Going Downhill but still hopeful to turn around

review_title: GE has dropped from the place to work to the place to leave in just the past few years.
pros: The GE name is still prestigious on a resume, and from the enthusiastic responses from prospective candidates that keep flooding the job boards, it might appear to be business as usual at the great GE of the past.  But that's not correct.
cons:
In the past few years, the culture at GE Appliances in Louisville has changed from one where employees truly believed that if they worked hard and did right by the company, the company would do right by them, to one where we feel like we are being actively being mislead by management.  

New cost cutting measures are launched  so often it is hard to keep up with them, and each reduction makes the job a harder by adding a burden or removing a benefit from employees and customers.  These changes are always announced with happy talk and pitched as improvements, in the form of easy to read elevator speeches that seem obviously written by a PR company.

Rather than call it what it is - when something is taken from you, it is a reduction in services, quality, benefits, and value.  So why can't they just stop sugar coating everything and acting like we are stupid.  

In the past week, GE and Electrolux jointly announced that GE was in talks with Electrolux to purchase our beloved appliance division, lock stock and barrel with Appliance Park Kentucky.   Even that announcement was written to dance around the truth, the announcement claimed that nothing was certain and the two companies were only involved in casual discussions, when the opposite is true.  

So now all the cost cutting and happy talk of the past few years makes sense:  we've been running on bubble gum and rubber bands to lower expenses so GE Appliances would be worth more.  With that spin removed, any fifth grader can see the truth of this situation:  what will happens next is that our loyal workers, most with more than a decade of service, will get flushed into an uncertain and dismal future just so that stockholders, who own stock in GE but not in the GE Appliance division, can make a few bucks while all this is going down and GE is continuing to apply "MADE IN AMERICA"  logos to all the appliances rolling out of Appliance Park, Kentucky.  

This division of  GE is the company that Thomas Edison formed in 1890, and Jeff Immelt is selling it to a company from Sweden that makes low quality appliances with bad service records.  They want to buy GE Appliances to fix their own problems.  But it never works like that, ask yourself where Maytag is after it was purchased by Whirlpool.  They still make a few Maytag appliances, but it is a shadow of what it used to be.  

My advice to job seekers:  Unless you are coming for a few months for an internship, I think you'd be crazy to come here now.  I probably don't need to tell you what happens when two companies are combined into one - but i'll give you a hint:  layoffs.

job_title: Senior Band Professional in Stamford, CT
pros: Many of GE companies are great to work for. GE Capital, Commercial Finance, former VFS (Vendor Financial Services), etc. Others, not so much. I was fortunate that Jack Welch was CEO for approx.  67% of my career with GE. Throughout this era employees BELIEVED in GE Values, embraced fantastic training tools such as Six Sigma, CAP (Change Acceleration Process), Leadership Training. Customer Satisfaction (referring to internal customers..GE Employees who engaged IT Client Services for support) was top priority. Employees/Teams worked in the office..together..engaged everyday with various teams. I loved getting up in the morning and going to work. Goals and Objectives were established during the first quarter of every year based on solid data. Projects/Tasks made sense. If an employee was a top performer there was no doubt she/he was on a solid, very timely career path.  to be continued below.
cons:
Then Mr. Welch left. All GE Capital IT employees were transferred to a centralized IT department under GE Corporate for phase one of the OneGE initiative. A centralized IT group serving all GE Verticals. Only a select one or two small GE divisions (small in regards to number of employees, but extremely integral to GE as a whole), Sigal Zarmi, one of the few female CIO's in Corporate America had the vision and foresight and COURAGE to push back. While the rest of GE IT..now Corporate IT..disintegrated quite rapidly with multiple cost cutting initiatives, outsourcing, so many re-orgs and name changes, team changes..impossible to keep count.  Morale of the majority of IT personal desperately treaded water but couldn't hold out. It began sinking and continues to sink to this very day. GE Values mean nothing, Spirit letter means nothing. 

Don't take my word for it..survey Corporate IT employees. Give them the following list of GE Core Values that drive Leadership and employees to excel.

*Strong Work Ethic: Valued employees who work hard and work smart
*Dependable/Reliable: Take Accountability for the teams they lead or projects they manage
*Positive Attitude and Embracing Change
*Adaptable and Flexible: Projects don't always go as planned. Adapt, think outside of the box, and motivate your team.
Ask them to rate them in order of importance. Also give them an option to rate ALL of them as EQUALLY IMPORTANT.

Now lets make a charitable David vs Goliath bet.  Me v.s. Glassdoor.  $5000 donated to the charity of choice. I will wager that over 94% will select the option that All of them are equally important.  It does not matter how many employees actually rate them. My wager? Less than 6% will reply back that the values listed are important but are NOT the GE CORE Values that are critical to the growth and success of General Electric

The real GE Values which truly ARE critical when INDIVIDUAL Goals and Objectives are identified in a one one one meeting with a manger. They are the following:
External focus
Show imagination and courage
Drive inclusiveness, 
Have expertise 
Clear thinkers

Most teams are virtual, in silos, have no idea what related teams are doing. The teams that were outsourced work in sweat shop environments. They are treated as lepers, beaten with a stick, not embraced as teammates. In my last months at GE, after engaging HR and the Ombudsperson because my boss was a bully, a former Army vet who treated employees as if they were in the Army at boot camp, not part of a team. Sticking up for the team who STRONGLY advised me NOT to go to HR as it is the kiss of death and told me flat out they would plead the fifth if approached. They all advised me to shut up, collect the paycheck, pay the bills, and be grateful I have a job.  I couldn't do that. I dreaded going to work each day. I was depressed..desperately searched for another job at GE and FOUND a perfect fit.
But it was AFTER I went to HR. I was not allowed to move. I was put on a performance plan.
When I was informed by my boss that I was being put on a performance plan (even though I achieved ALL my Goals and Objectives along with additional stretch goals) I explained that I needed a change after working for 4 years on a team that was constantly in flux, no stability, four managers in four years...my manager informed me that I COULD interview for the position, saw no reason why I couldn't move but he wanted to discuss it with HR first. End result, I was NOT allowed to interview..was put on a plan. 

The rest is history. I could literally write a book about Corporate IT. It would be incredibly entertaining. Solidly backup my claims with data. The scandal stories alone would make it a best seller.  I decided not too because I am grateful for the fantastic managers I had in my early years. Grateful for the wide skill set I developed in those early years. And my last 4 or 5 years? I was schooled with 500+ examples of how NOT to lead, manage projects, treat people.

review_title: Used to be good, but activist investors are ruining it for the employees
pros: Dedicated to integrity. Interesting work. Respectable company with good management. I love GE, I love what we do, and I love what the company stands for. We're not afraid to make bold moves, and despite a heavy burden of bureaucracy, we do big, important, world-changing things. We are transforming factories and machines for the digital era by instrumenting them with sensors, connecting them to a homegrown cloud platform, and helping our partners to build transformative apps to improve their businesses based on analysis of the data ... and if that by itself weren't enough, we make trains, planes, and power plants while were at it.  So when I write this review, know that it's with a heavy heart - I always have, and still do LOVE GE, what we do, and what the company stands for, and I will do everything in my power to make sure that GE returns to not only a company that does great things, but also great place to be while getting them done.
cons:
Our cash flow on industrial operations was bad last quarter. Lay people off, oust the CEO, set aggressive targets tied to exec bonuses bad. This in itself isn't a con - businesses have cycles, industry waxes and wanes, and along the way there will be hirings and firings, business class and coach, fat raises and thin. We all understand this, and I don't begrudge the company letting people go of people to make ends meet. We all make cutbacks in our lives when times are hard, the government should do it, and corporations -have- to do it.  I don't even begrudge the board the executive bonus increases and decreases that are tied to the 2017 and 2018 1B savings targets -- targets that big have to be driven from the top down, hard decisions need to be made, and if the right decisions are made intelligently, they've earned their bonuses.  In fact, were I in Jeff Immelt's shoes with an activist investor breathing down my neck demanding my job, I'd make many of the same moves he's making. So why the 1 star review, when I love the company, understand the cuts, and agree that we need to get back to positive cashflow?

The cut the already miserly 'above and beyond' bonus program. While this in itself isn't a big deal, it signals to me that the management layers have given up on morale, engagement, and everything that goes with it. The bang-for-buck of employee activities like affinity groups (which have also had their funding cut), holiday parties, and 'thank-you' bonus programs is unmatched, and to see these things go means that not only have they made cuts with heavy hearts, they've moved to a point where they just don't care about morale among the rank-and-file anymore. For this reason, I can only recommend that you stay away until better times return.
